identified by his GP but not reported. The second finding included an 85- year-old women who 
drove through a T intersection without braking, swerved and hit a tree which was likely caused by progressive cognitive decline over  7 years,  which neither  the GP or psychiatrist  reported  this to  the

truck  veered across  the road and up  an embankment causing it to roll. His  death was  likely caused

The driver  was deemed  fit to drive  by a medical  practitioner, despite  his cardiac history  however, 
there was no report to the DLA outlining the driving risk (Magistrates Court of Tasmania, 2017).

CRICOS  Provider  No. 00103D  | RTO  Code  4909  Page 13  of 84  What  is the occupational  therapy driver assessor’s  role? 
Within Australia, occupational therapists have been formally involved in assisting people with 
health conditions to drive for over twenty years (Unsworth, 2007). These occupational therapists complete post -graduate training in driver assessment and intervention to become occupational 
therapy  driver  assessors (OTDAs), an advanced  scope of practice.  OTDAs  are trained to complete

chunk_953.text:
a two -phased process  which includes a comprehensive off -road and a practical on- road 
assessment.  
The off -road assessment  involves gathering information on driving history, the  need and desire  for 
driving, medical history, physical, sensory, and cognitive assessment and road law and road craft knowledge testing. Information gained from the off- road assessment is used to assist with 
identifying areas for further assessment during  the on- road assessment. The on- road assessment 
is conducted with a driving instructor (in the driving instructors car) for safety purposes. Findings from the off and on -road assessment are then combined to make a recommendation regarding 
whether an individual is safe for driving, safe for driving with certain conditions on their licence or unsafe f or driving. Recommendations for on- road rehabilitation are often suggested, with periodic 
re-assessments  when required. These  recommendations are  provided either to the treating doctor

chunk_954.text:
re-assessments  when required. These  recommendations are  provided either to the treating doctor 
and/or the licencing authority who makes final licencing decisions. For  state -based jurisdictional 
differences regarding the OTDA role, please refer to Appendix A.  
While all OTDA's complete the same training to become an OTDA, some OTDA's will complete further training to specialize in certain areas for example, vehicle modifications. Therefore, when referring onto a OTDA for comprehensive assessment it is important to specify the reason for further assessment to ensure that the OTDA is able to address the area of concern.

Occupational Therapy Australia (OTA) confirm that “community mobility is a core scope of 
practice  for occupational  therapy.  All occupational  therapists understand the occupation  of 
driving a vehicle as an instrumental activity of daily living enabling community

mobility”  (Occupational  Therapy  Australia,  2015,  p.3). Why  does  this matter?  
Understanding the role of occupational therapists who have completed further training in 
driver  assessment  and rehabilitation  is important  to be able to discriminate between your role 
and when you may refer or seek  further  advice.

Commencement  of driving  discussions  
You have  a duty of care and professional  obligation to address  all daily occupations  as part of  your 
usual scope of practice and this includes driving. During the initial consultations with your clients, you need to ensure that you are gathering information about your client’s driving history.  
Identification  of driving as a meaningful  occupation and goal 
You then need  to gather  information about whether your client wishes  to continue driving and/or

chunk_958.text:
You then need  to gather  information about whether your client wishes  to continue driving and/or 
whether they wish to return to driving if they have ceased driving. If so, driving should be documented as a goal in the client’s file. This goal should meet SMART principles and include:  
Specific – Where does the client want to drive? How long does it take to get to the destination/s? 
How often does  the client wish  to drive? Who with? In  which car  will they drive? Is  this automatic or 
manual? Do they need any technology to assist for example, navigation systems?  
Measurable – How will you know  if the goal is achieved? What  progress  has been made? 
Achievable – What resources do they need to achieve this goal? Do they need an OT driving 
assessment? Considering their  current  medical  conditions, is  this realistic  for the client now  and in 
the future? Is driving an automatic or manual car realistic? 
Relevant  – Why do they want  to drive?

chunk_959.text:

Time -bound – By when? After a  period of rehabilitation?  
An example  of a SMART  driving  goal may be: 
“To able to return  to driving an automatic car every day in order  to independently get  to/from the 
shops and my local GP, as well as drive my wife to social outings and visit my grandchildren by 
the end of October 2022”.  
Administration of physical,  sensory,  and cognitive  assessments 
You use a  range of physical, sensory,  and cognitive screening tools  and assessments  as part  of 
usual practice that can be used when thinking about driving as an  occupation. For  example, you 
may complete the Mini Mental State Examination ( MMSE) (Folstein et al., 1975) to determine 
whether the client will have issues with knowing when and whether they will remember to take their medication. The MMSE may also be completed to determine whether the client may have difficulty with remembering road rules.

involves  the application  of observational  skills  to assess and analyse  occupational  performance. 
For example, observing a client preparing a meal to determine whether they have any cognitive impairments. These observations are often used to inform intervention planning for a range of occupations, but these can also be applied to driving.  
Provision of rehabilitation  for deficits  in physical,  sensory,  and cognitive 
impairments  
Following assessment, you provide rehabilitation to remediate physical, sensory, and cognitive impairments and  reduce  their impact  on client  occupational performance in  a range of occupations.

It is important to provide rehabilitation to achieve short term goals first, such as cooking a meal in order to work towards longer term goals such as driving. Addressing impairments in simple occupations  first can  indirectly  assist with im proving readiness  and potential  for return  to driving, as 
skills required for simple occupations are needed before more complex skills can be remediated such as those required for driving.

CRICOS  Provider  No. 00103D  | RTO  Code  4909  Page 16  of 84  Education of medical  clearance processes  and insurance  liability  
As an occupational therapist your duty of care and professional obligation involves educating 
clients concerning their responsibilities as a driver. This includes reporting any potential long- term 
or permanent health conditions that could impair their driving skills to the DLA. It is important to educate your clients that by reporting their health conditions to the DLA, that it does not mean that 
the DLA will automatically  revoke their licence,  however  it is necessary  to meet  legal  requirements. 
However, this reporting to the DLA should only occur when the client is ready to return to driving. 
The education you provide to your clients  should also involve  informing them  of their responsibility

chunk_964.text:
to notify their insurance companies of any potential long- term or permanent health conditions.  
You should inform your clients to check with their insurance companies’ disclosure statements to ensure that coverage is provided despite their medical condition/s. It is important to educate your clients that if  they fail to do this, it may result in  their insurance  coverage  being affected  if they are 
involved in an accident, as a result of not complying with their legal requirements to report  
long- term or permanent  health conditions.  See section 5 for client  education handout.  
Provision of driving counselling  when  driving is no longer  safe 
All drivers will have to cease driving at some point in time in their life and receiving appropriate 
counselling when driving  is no longer safe is important  to maintain quality  of life. See section 5 for 
resources to support driving counselling conversations.  
Exploration  of other  community  mobility  options

Exploration  of other  community  mobility  options  
The extensive skills  you possess  in supporting community  mobility  participation  can guide clients  to 
have greater  autonomy,  freedom  and confidence  when accessing the wider community.  If driving  is 
no longer safe, then you have a role in assisting your clients to explore other ways to access the community for example public transport training, scooter use, taxi, community services, safe walking etc. This will assist with minimising the impact of driving cessation and ensuring that your clients are safe within their community

2.1 Profile  of novice  drivers  
Obtaining a drivers licence is considered a milestone among adolescence and young adults (Cox et al., 2016).  While  driving  is an efficient  form of transportation 
and is a step towards  gaining independence from family 
(Constantinou et al., 2011), driving offers increased opportunities for paid employment and future plans for study (Cox et al., 2016). For young adults driving also adds to the development of personal identity and peer acceptance which are both important factors for this population (Constantinou et al., 2011).

Young adults possess a range of human factors that impact on driving safety such as cognition, fatigue, alcohol and engagement in risky and/or aggressive behaviours, which places them at a significantly higher risk of being involved in a collision than compared to any other age group (Constantinou et al., 2011). Evidence  suggests  that young adults are  more likely to engage  in 
risk- taking behaviours (Constantinou et al., 2011). This may be partly due to the ongoing 
development of the frontal regions of their  brains particularly, executive functions which are 
responsible for inhibition, reasoning and decision making (Constantinou et al., 2011).  In addition,

chunk_980.text:
young adults are still developing their driving skills, so when coupled with alcohol, drug use, peer pressure and fatigue, young adults often overestimate their skills and underestimate the driving task which contributes to an increased risk of accident (Constantinou et al., 2011).  
For those young adults who have been diagnosed with a health condition, obtaining a drivers licence is much more difficult than compared with their peers (Cox et al., 2016). Evidence suggests that young adults with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) have 
diminished executive functioning which causes difficulty with sustained attention, reduced resistance to distractions and poor self -monitoring which are crucial skills for driving (Barkley et 
al., 2002). In addition to reduced executive functioning, young adults with Autism experience an increased likelihood of becoming anxious  while driving and are also less likely to  identify  socially

chunk_981.text:
relevant road hazards such as pedestrians walking out (Cox et al., 2016). There is also an increased association with co- existing conditions such as anxiety and depression which in 
isolation also can impact on driving safety (Barkley et al., 2002).

2.2 Profile  of adult  drivers  with health  conditions  
Driving continues to be the main form of transport, representing 69% of working adults. 
Additionally, a further 5% of adults travel as passengers in a car for work and/or study purposes 
(Australian Bureau of Statistics,  2017). For  this population group, driving represents  an easy and 
efficient mode of transport to fulfill life roles such as being a parent, worker and/or carer. 
While there is a significant amount of driving research for both young and older adults, minimal research exists for middle- aged adults. Research has outlined that one’s driving experience has 
been linked with increased driving efficacy (León -Domínguez et al.,  2017), highlighting that more 
experienced drivers are able to detect hazards sooner and have increased problem solving on the road (León- Domínguez et al., 2017). However, distracted driving among middle- aged

chunk_983.text:
adults is high including phone use, and the presence of children in cars. This is likely due to family and work obligations combined with an overconfidence in driving skill (Engelberg et al., 2015).  
There are many caus al factors that can impact on driving safety and accidents, however the 
presence of medical conditions which cause serious impairments is a significant contributor to road safety (Austroads, 2022). The Austroads fitness to drive guidelines, outline a range  of 
medical conditions likely to affect driving but these guidelines also acknowledge that it is not possible to define all conditions or  a combination of conditions  that could affect a  person’s driving 
ability (Austroads, 2022). The guidelines also highlight that  the condition itself may not impact on

chunk_984.text:
driving however possible side effects from medications can affect driving and these must also be appropriately assessed. It is important to consider the variety or perhaps multitude of health conditions that can impact on driving, however particular focus should be placed on 
conditions that affect cognitive and perceptual skills, as these conditions are less able to be compensated for unlike conditions that only affect physical skills that can easily be 
compensated for with adaptive equipment such as a spinner knob for one -handed steering 
(Unsworth, 2009).  
Health professionals need to better understand the impact of health conditions on driving 
performance  to either support  safe driving  if possible and/or  support  community  mobility when 
driving is considered unsafe.

adults also means that they are more likely to have serious injuries or die when involved in vehicle crashes when compared to other age groups (Koppel et al., 2011; Lantz, 2007). When  
older drivers are involved in car accidents, evidence has shown that this occurs in the following road environments including, complex intersections, railway crossings,  roadwork and constructions 
areas, high speed interchanges such  as freeways, and road curves (Unsworth, 2009).  
While a general decline in physical, cognitive and sensory skills has been associated with the ageing process (Baldock et al., 2006), driving skills are more often impacted by health 
conditions that are acquired with age (Moon et al., 2018). Health conditions such as stroke,

Additionally, the aged population have the highest percentage of medication use such as, benzodiazepines which can also impact on driving skills (Lloyd et al., 2001).  
Studies have shown that some older drivers with cognitive changes can compensate for reduced driving skills  through self-regulation of their  driving behaviours, which  may result  in 
maintaining their licence for prolonged periods of time despite the presence of health conditions (Unsworth et al., 2007).  Some self -restricting behaviours include not driving at night, driving within 
close proximately to home, and allowing increased gap selection between the vehicle in front.

Two ways to evaluate driving are documented in the literature: screening and assessment. 
Screening refers to the use of a few tools to obtain and review data to determine the need for 
further evaluation (Transportation Research Board, 2016). In contrast, assessment refers to the 
use of a battery of tools to comprehensively gather information which may involve reviewing medical history, use of clinical assessments and on- road driving assessment (Transportation 
Research Board,  2016).  Literature  supporting driving screening  and assessment  practices  among 
professional groups are described below.

practices?  
There is currently  no descriptive or experimental  literature used  by the licencing  authority

for the assessment of people who do not have a health problem. For those people with an identified health condition, further assessment is requested from health professionals who use standardised assessments tools to assess risk and mak e fitness to drive recommendations.  
In terms of on road assessments, a small proportion of licensing authorities’ driving instructors complete these assessments for only those people without an identified health condition. There 
is limited evidence to suggest this on- road assessment is standardised, when compared  
to on- road assessments completed by OTDAs which are based on set competency 
guidelines (Catchpole & Di Stefano, 2018). Many people who fail their DLA on- road assessment

Step  1. Identify  your  client’s  needs  for community  mobility  
Community mobility is defined as “moving around in the community and using public or private 
transportation such as driving,  walking, bicycling,  or accessing and riding  in buses,  taxi cabs,  or 
other transportation systems” (American Occupational Therapy Association, 2021, p. 1).

chunk_1012.text:
other transportation systems” (American Occupational Therapy Association, 2021, p. 1).  
Community mobility provides individuals with independence, freedom, and links to their 
occupational identities.  Its purpose is to enable transportation from one place to another  to enable 
people to participate in other occupations of meaning and purpose.  
The role you have in evaluating safety  and providing interventions  to address  community  mobility 
issues varies and may include:  
•Screening for passenger  safety  ie. Seating,  positioning,  seatbelt  use, cognitive or
behavioural impairments that may impact on driver safety
•Assessing abilities  to cross the road and negotiate curbs
•Reading signage
•Driving  readiness  and ongoing safety
•Public  transport  access  and re-training
•Creating transportation alternatives  and community  resources
•Scooter  assessment  and/or  prescription

chunk_1013.text:
•Scooter  assessment  and/or  prescription
If driving  is no longer  considered safe,  then exploring other  forms  of community  mobility  through 
appropriate assessment and intervention is required to maintain independence, freedom, and 
occupational participation in the community. 
Step  2. Identify  if driving  is a valued occupation  
During  initial interactions  with your client, you have  gathered  information  to determine if driving  is a 
valued occupation. This may involve clients who are currently driving, who wish to continue to drive, and clients who have ceased driving who wish to return to driving.  
Here  are some  questions  that may assist you in understanding the importance  of driving  with your 
clients:  
•Is driving  important  to you?
•What  does  driving  enable you to do?
•Does  your partner  or family  member  drive  too?
•Would it be easier  or harder  to fulfill your usual  routine if you could no longer
drive?

would you get there?

 age 31  of 84  Step  3. Conduct  screening  assessments  
If your client values  driving as an occupation and wants  to continue/resume driving,  then you may 
consider conducting screening assessments. As part of medical fitness to drive guidelines, there 
are range of vision standards for driving clearance (Austroads, 2022). These include:  
•Visual  acuity (with  or without  glasses)  of 6/12
•Visual  fields  <120 degrees  horizontal  plane
Your client must meet these visual standards in order to progress any further with the driving process as per the Austroads medical standards. You can refer to any optometrist or

chunk_1015.text:
orthoptist and request completion of the DLA eyesight report to obtain visual clearance for driving standards. Note:  any visual  defects  should prompt  a referral  to an optometrist or  orthoptist  for a full 
visual assessment.  
The Bells  test (Gauthier  et al., 1989) is  used  to assess for the presence of unilateral  neglect  which 
may be present in clients with neurological problems. If the client presents with unilateral neglect, then the client is not safe to pursue the driving process (Unsworth, 2011). If the client has demonstrated >4 errors it is likely that that your client is unsafe to drive (Mazer et al., 1998). 
Generally, research has shown that neglect persisting greater than 3 months post neurological event is  unlikely  to resolve (Hier  et al., 1983),  therefore the client  should be educated on driving 
cessation and to explore other community mobility alternatives (refer to step 1).

This section details how  to administer  screening assessment tools which includes procedures, 
scoring methods and where to source this relevant information.  
For administration of other standardised and performance -based tools, please refer to Table 5 on 
where to source the tool which will provide further information within the associated manuals.  
Visual  acuity 
Visual  acuity  is assessed  by a Snellen Chart  (20 ft/6m). 
Note: although  there  are various  free versions  available  online these are not always  reliable  due to

chunk_1036.text:
inaccurate sizing,  therefore it  is recommended to purchase your own Snellen chart (see Table 5 of 
where to source Snellen Charts).  
What  do you need  to do? 
•Position  the Snellen chart  6m from the client’s  eye level.
•Ask the client  to stand at the appropriate  location  and cover one eye.
•Ask the client  to read the letters  out loud,  beginning from the left-hand  side of the top row.
•Repeat this  process  for the opposite eye and if the client wears  glasses  (with  their glasses
on).

acuity (with or without glasses) in order to drive (Austroads, 2022; Unsworth, 2011). If the client 
makes any errors with visual acuity, consider a referral to an optometrist or orthoptist for further assessmen t.

What  do you need  to do? 
•Position  yourself  in a seated position opposite the client  with your knees  touching.
•Ask the client  to remove  any glasses  and to cover  one eye.

head, then move it in and arc beginning on a vertical plane outside of the client’s vision
then into the midline. Repeat this on a horizontal plane.
•Ask the client  to “look  at my nose;  do not look  anywhere else.  Tell me when  you can see
the red dot out of the corner of your eye” (Unsworth, 2011, p. 19).

Below  are a series  of questions  and answers  developed to assist clinicians  with some complex 
decision making when determining driving process recommendations.  
How  long is my client  not allowed  to drive for once they get home  from  hospital,  and who 
do they need to get permission from to resume driving?  
There are no specific time frames restricting a person from driving as each individual is different. 
The Austroads Assessing Fitness to Drive Guidelines (Austroads, 2022) outline the medical standards  for driving.  You can inform  your client  that they will need to seek  medical  clearance prior

chunk_1049.text:
to resuming driving, which is completed by a medical professional in the hospital or community.  
You can also inform your client that while they may be medically fit to resume driving, they may experience some functional impairments that could impact on their driving therefore further assessment and  recommendations  from a non-driver  trained occupational  therapist  may also be 
needed.  
What  do you do if my client  reports they feel fine to drive?  Can they just resume  driving? 
No, your client  must  seek  medical  clearance before returning to driving.  You must also ensure that 
you have fully assessed your client to make sure that there are no ongoing functional limitations that may impact on driving.  
My client  reports “my rehab doctor  has said that I can’t  drive for 4-6 weeks.  Will they notify 
my GP or licensing authority?” Is this correct? 
Following time in hospital, a  medical practitioner  will provide a detailed discharge summary to  the

chunk_1050.text:
clients GP, which should include recommendations about driving. Inpatient medical practitioner’s 
will not often  notify the licensing authority as following this period, as clients may present with no 
ongoing impairments  that could impact  on driving  therefore  there  is no need to notify  the licensing 
authority  or, it may be too early to determine the permanent impact of the health condition on 
driving. Therefore, i t is important  that appropriate follow up is in place in the community  to ensure  
that their condition is monitored to determine if there are potential safety concerns driving and 
therefore if notification is required.  
When does  my client  have to notify  the licensing authority  of their  change in health  status? 
This may very between states, however your client should inform the licensing authority (usually 
through obtaining medical  clearance and completion of the medical  report)  when they are ready  to 
commence the driving process.

chunk_1051.text:
commence the driving process.  
Prior to this, you should inform your client that they are unable to drive until the complete the 
necessary steps are taken ie. await further recovery, obtain medical clearance. However, if you 
have concerns regarding your client’s ability to comply with your recommendation for example, reduced insight into their impairments and therefore there are potential safety risks you have a duty of care  to notify  the licencing authority earlier. This may  result in  licence conditions being put 
on their licence to restrict their driving until the appropriate steps are completed.

My client  is from  interstate and wishes to resume driving,  what  do you do? 
There may be a few different pathways that your client can follow depending on whether they are planning to return to their original state or whether they plan on remaining in their current state. If your client has a new  medical condition and they are planning to return to their original state, then 
they need to notify the DLA of the state in which their licence was issued. However, if your client wishes to remain in the current state for greater than 6 months then they need to visit a customer 
service centre  to complete a  transfer of licence application form. They  will need to  outline whether

chunk_1057.text:
they have any medical conditions that may impact on driving here and depending on the type and severity of the medical condition the DLA may either transfer their licence pending a new medical report  OR they may refuse  the transfer  of licence until a medical report with  clearance is provided.  
My client  is awaiting  medical  clearance,  are they still able to supervise a learner  driver?  
No. Your client needs to be medically and functionally fit to be able to supervise a learner driver. 
This is because if something was to happen  with the learner  driver, your  client needs  to be able to 
take over control of the vehicle which requires them to have medical clearance and deemed 
functionally suitable to operate a motor vehicle. 
My client self  restricts  their driving  by only driving locally  and during the day. Do they need 
to inform the DLA or have an OT driving assessment?

chunk_1058.text:
to inform the DLA or have an OT driving assessment?  
No. Your client may be self -restricting to maintain the longevity of their licence, however they be 
self-restricting due to underlying medical changes which is affecting their driving skills. It is 
recommended that they discuss driving with their GP at regular intervals to maintain their medical fitness  to drive.  You should also inform  your client  that if they recognize  any changes  in their health 
that could impact their driving that they notify their GP as this may affect their insurance. You m ay 
want to discuss this with a family member (if possible) to increase the likelihood of this occurring.

Occupational  Therapist  or Occupational  Therapy.  
OTDA  refers  to an Occupational  Therapy  Driver  Assessor who has completed additional training to 
specialize in driving assessment and rehabilitation. Non- OTDA’s are occupational therapists with 
either undergraduate or post -graduate training to become occupational therapists, however, are 
not trained to complete comprehensive driving evaluations.  
DLA 
Driver’s  License  Authority  refers  to the licensing  agency  within  each Australian  state.  This agency 
differs  across  the states  however, the roles  and responsibilities  of the licensing  agencies  includes 
decision making about licensing conditions.  
GP 
General Practitioner is a doctor who is also qualified in general practice medicine. They treat a 
wide variety  of health conditions  and are usually  the first point of  medical  contact  for people in the

chunk_1079.text:
community.

Why  is driving a privilege?  
Many people consider driving a 
meaningful activity as it provides freedom, independence and enjoyment. However, there are certain responsibilities you have as a driver to make sure that you are safe 
to drive. Driving a car is a complex skill 
that requires good physical and cognitive skills. There  are different health conditions 
that can impact on these skills, which may 
affect your ability to drive safely. Just 
because you have a health condition, it does not mean that you will not be able to drive. It might mean that you have to 
regularly  check  with your medical  or health 
professional that your condition is well 
managed to enable you to continue  
driving.  
What  are my responsibilities  as a 
driver?  
As a driver, you are required by law to 
report  to your  driver  licencing authority 
any permanent  or long -term  illness that 
is likely to affect your ability to drive safely . Your doctor will be able to advise

chunk_1134.text:
is likely to affect your ability to drive safely . Your doctor will be able to advise 
whether or not you should be reporting your condition to the licencing authority or not. When reporting your condition to the 
licencing authority, it does not mean that 
your licence will be taken away. It means that your medical and health professional teams can work with the licencing 
authority together to help manage your 
condition with respect to driving. This is also important because if you continue driving  without  obtaining medical  approval, 
or fail to notify the licencing autho rity of 
any permanent or long- term illness and 
you are involved in an accident; you may be criminally liable and your insurance 
may not cover you. It is important to also 
notify your insurance company as  
changes to your policy may be required. Who  decides  if I am able to drive?  
Driving screens or assessments can be 
completed by medical or health 
professionals.  These  assessments  are not

chunk_1135.text:
completed by medical or health 
professionals.  These  assessments  are not 
used to decide if you are allowed to drive 
or not but helps to inform whether further 
assessments are needed. These health professionals have a responsibility to inform the licencing authority if the patient 
may be at risk of driving  unsafely.  In some 
instances,  people require  an Occupational 
Therapy driving assessment to make  sure 
they are safe  to drive. The driver licencing 
authority will inform you if this is needed. 
However, the driver licencing authority makes the final decisions about your licence status, not your health care 
team.  
Who  do I contact  for further 
information?  
For more  information  you can contact  your

territory via the contact details on the Austroads  website www.austroads.com.au

 Abstract  
Introduction  
In Australia, all stroke survivors are restricted in driving for four weeks , and persons who 
experience a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA) are restricted in driving for two weeks. All health 
professionals working in stroke and TIA have a responsibility to provide written and verbal

chunk_1171.text:
professionals working in stroke and TIA have a responsibility to provide written and verbal 
information on return  to driving  (RTD) to persons with stroke or TIA and provide them with a n 
RTD management pl an prior to discharge from hospital.  
 
Aim 
This thesis  aims to determine whether Austroads ’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines and  the National 
Stroke Foundation ’s Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management are being met in the 
multiprofessional team’s role in pro viding RTD education  to stroke survivors and in facilitating 
stroke survivors ’ adherence to driving restrictions.  
 
Methodology  
Study one is a systematic review of adherence to RTD guidelines and legislation following stroke. 
Study two reports on a medical record audit of inpatient documentation related to the provision 
of RTD education and management plans in the acute hospital setting , and the results of an 
anonymous patient survey of RTD behaviours. Study three prese nts the findings from a survey

chunk_1172.text:
anonymous patient survey of RTD behaviours. Study three prese nts the findings from a survey 
of Australian health professionals working in the field of stroke regarding the knowledge and 
use of RTD guidelines. Study four reports on the development and implementation of an 
electronic learning module on RTD , targeting Australian health professionals working in the field 
of stroke.  
33
 
 
 Results  
The systematic review revealed only three studies , all based in the United Kingdom,  that 
investigated the provision of RTD education in the acute hospital setting . The medical record 
audit revealed that patients with stroke or TIA are not routinely receiv ing documentation on the 
provision of education on RTD prior to discharge from hospital . The anonymous patient survey 
revealed that , if provided with education on RTD, a person with st roke or TIA will follow the 
advice give n. The results of the national survey of health professionals revealed that health

chunk_1173.text:
advice give n. The results of the national survey of health professionals revealed that health 
professionals lack knowledge about RTD guidelines , and the management of RTD is being 
deferred to other health professionals. The deve lopment of an electronic learning module on 
RTD after stroke , targeting Australian health professionals , is bridging the practice -evidence gap 
in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines after stroke and TIA.    
 
Conclusion  
The provis ion of education on res trictions in driving , and RTD management plans , in patients 
with stroke and TIA who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting is not well -
managed. Strategies need to be developed and implemented to ensure all patients with stroke 
and TIA  who are discharged home from the acute hospital setting receive nationally -
recommended education on driving restrictions , and RTD management plans.

 1.1 Background  
A stroke occurs when the blood supply to the brain is interrupted , causing damage to, or death 
of brain tissue. The effects of stroke can include weakness in arms  and legs, and difficulty with 
speaking, thinking and vision. Stroke occurs in approximately 60,000 people in Australia each 
year , and stroke is Aus tralia’s second largest killer and cause of disability  (National Stroke 
Foundation, 2010b ). A major predictor of a patient’s return to independence post -stroke , and 
hence quality of life , is the ability to drive  (Poole, Chaudry, & Jay, 2008 ). In Australia, all survivors 
are restricted in driving for four weeks  after stroke and for two weeks after transient isch aemic 
attack (TIA) (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ).  
 
1.2 Rationale

 2.1 Stroke  and transient ischaemic attack   
Stroke is classified as either ischaemic, resulting from a blockage in a cerebral artery leading to

Thomas, & Pandey, 2008 ). Stroke is one of Australia’s largest causes of death and disability. Each 
year, 6 0,000 Australians experience stroke s, and one in six people will experience stroke s in their 
lifetime s. Over 50% of new or recurrent strokes affect those aged over 75 years of age. Stroke is 
estimated to cost the Australian community $5 billion a year (Aust ralian Institute of Health and 
Welfare, 2013 ). 
 
One-third of people with stroke experience impairments that impact their ability to carry out 
everyday activities (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2013 ). Impairments resulting 
from stroke can be classified as motor (Lawrence, Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001 ), sensory (Carey 
& Matyas, 2011 ), vision (Fisk et al., 2002 ), language (Brady, Kelly, Godwin, Enderby, & Campbell,

occur in isolation or in combination and can affect a person’s ability to walk, talk, eat, drink and 
perform activities  of daily living. The most common impairment resulting from stroke is upper 
limb and lower limb motor weakness, which is experienced by over 70% of stroke survivors 
(Lawrence, Coshall, Dundad, et al., 2001 ). Other impairments can impact a person’s ability to 
effectively communicate with others, for example, dysphagia , and ability to accurate perceive 
and interpret the surrounding environment, for example, homonymous hemianopia. As many

Stroke causes permanent damage to the brain. This is often preceded by  a transient ischaemic 
attack ( TIA) (Rothwell et al., 2005 ). A TIA has been traditionally defined as a sudden neurological 
event lasting less than 24 hours (Ad Hoc Committee on Cerebrovascular Diseases, 1990 ) and not 
resulting in any permanent brain  damage (Lewandowski, Chathan, & Silver, 2008 ). However, 
with advances in neuroimaging, this definition and description is under challenge. A person with 
a TIA will experience similar impairments to those of stroke , such as  hemiparesis (arm and/or 
leg weakness), sensory disturbances, facial weakness, dysphasia and/or visual disturbances. 
Symp toms can last anywhere from several minutes to several hours (Lewandowski et al., 2008 ) 
and may be viewed as benign, particularly if they last for less than an hour (Easton et al., 2009 ).

 The risk of stroke following TIA is high , with research indicating that a person with a TIA has a 1 
in 10 chance of having a full stroke in the next three months. Fifty percent of those who then  
have a stroke will do so within t he next two days (Johnston, Gres s, Browner, & Sidney, 2000 ). 
Advances in the use of magnetic resonance imaging have challenged the traditional “transient” 
notion of TIAs, with results revealing that despite the resolution of symptoms following a TIA, 
irreversible brain damage has, in fact, occurred (Johnston, 2002 ). Evidence shows that people 
with TIA who experience symptoms for longer than one hour are less likely to experience a full 
recovery (Levy, 1988 ) and are more  likely to have infarcts  that are  detectable via neuroimaging 
and are similar to those observed after stroke (Easton et al., 2009 ; Kidwell, Alger, & Di Salle, 
1999 ; Oppenheima et al., 2006 ). This re search demonstrates that a TIA is, in fact, a minor

chunk_1195.text:

ischaemic stroke and, because of its significance regarding  the risk of recurrent stroke, is a 
significant medical event that should not be left untreated (Dutta, Bowen, & Foy, 2015 ). 
 
In Australia, when a person is experiencing stroke -like symptoms, they should be immediately 
trans ported to hospital via the Ambulance Service to ensure they receive the best -available 
hyper -acute management. Once the stroke event has fully resolved, the next phase of functional 
recovery starts. Those diagnosed with mild stroke or TIA may be discharged  directly home from 
a hospital’s emergency department or from the acute setting. In many cases, following discharge 
their ongoing care will be managed by their local doctor s or, in the first 6 -8 weeks, by 
neurologist s. In the sub -acute phase of care, those  diagnosed with more severe stroke may be

chunk_1196.text:
neurologist s. In the sub -acute phase of care, those  diagnosed with more severe stroke may be 
referred to inpatient rehabilitation, and this may be followed up eventually with community -
based or home -based rehabilitation (Agency for Clinical Innovation, 2016 ).

 There are many health professionals involved in the care of a person who experiences a stroke. 
Organised stroke care coordinated by a multidisciplinary team provides the stroke survivor  with 
the best outcomes with regard to returning home to live independently (Stroke Unit Trialists, 
2013 ). The multidisciplinary team consist s of medical, nursing and allied health staff.  Examples 
of the allied health professions that may be involved in stroke rehabilitation include 
physiotherapy, occupational therapy,  speech pathology, dietetics and social work. 
Physiotherapy is the most commonly received allied health service provided to stroke survivors

in hospital, followed by occupational therapy and speech pathology. However, not all stroke

are many different pathways of health  care for survivors of stroke and TIA, how are issues such

2.2 Stroke and d riving a motor vehicle  
In Australia, a person is able to obtain a provisional driving licence from the age of 17 (Roads 
and Maritime Services, 2016 ), and for many, driving is seen as a necessity (Mazer et al., 2003 ) 
rather than a privilege. It is noted that a  person makes approximately 20 decisions each 
kilometre he or she drives (American Automobile Association, 2016 ). Driving is considered an

instrumental activity of daily living (Dickerson, Reist etter, Schold Davis, & Monahan, 2011 ) and 
a major contributor to a person’s quality of life and satisfaction (Devos et al., 2011 ; Mazer et al., 
2003 ; White et al., 2012 ). Driving promotes independence and increases choices related to 
occupations  and social engagement (White et al., 2012 ). For example, being able to drive a 
motor vehicle can be essential to someone’s ability to engage in employment -related 
occupations and fulfil life roles (Mazer et al., 2003 ; Stav & Pierce, 2010 ). An inability to drive  can

a continual basis, often without conscious effort” (Mazer, Gelinas, & Benoit, 2004, p. 292 ).

The complex nature of driving a motor vehicle can be explained using the Person -Environment -
Occupation Performance (PEOP) model (Christiansen, Baum, & Bass -Hagen, 2005 ). According to 
this model, a person’s occupational performance is “the outcome of the transaction of the 
person, environment and occupation. It is defined as the dynamic experience of a person 
engaged in purposeful activities and tasks within an environment” (Law et al., 1996, p. 16 ). 
Figure 2.1 demonstrates how the successful driving of a motor vehicle is reliant on the 
“transactions” between the: 
• Intrinsic “person”: the combination of visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and cognitive 
skills ; the driver’s ability , including previous ly learnt skills and past driving experiences 
(Akinwuntan, Wachtel, & Rosen, 2012 ); and psychosocial factors such as confidence and 
mood

mood  
• Extrinsic “environment”: the vehicle , road conditions, traffic conditions, number of 
passengers, weather conditions, and driving ability (Akinwuntan et al., 2012 ; Mazer et 
al., 2003 ) 
• Occupations: the activities and tasks that contribute to occupational performance 
(Christiansen et al., 2005 ; Law et al., 1996 ).

transactions potentially break down.

2.3  Return -to-driving guidelines and legislation  
In Australia, there  are six States and two Territories , and each has its own government -led Driver 
Licensing Authority (DLA). A DLA is responsible for the issuing, renewing, suspending, refusing 
or cancelling of a person’s driver’s licence, taking into consideration the heal th and driving

record of the licence holder (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ). There are 
two types of licences in Australia. The first is a Private Licence, which is required to drive a 
motorcy cle, car or light rigid vehicle for personal use. A light rigid vehicle is one that is greater 
than four and a half tonnes but less than eight tonnes or can carry more than 12 people. The 
second is a Commercial Licence , which is required when driving a veh icle as a source of income 
or when the vehicle is a medium rigid (a two-axle small truck or bus over eight tonnes), heavy 
rigid (a three -axle big truck or  bus), heavy combination (semi -trailer) or multiple combination 
vehicle (heavy combination with additi onal trailer/s) (Austroads and National Transport 
Commission, 2016 ).

Impairments resulting from stroke, including visuoperceptual, sensorimotor and cognitive  
impairments , can impact a person’s ability to drive a motor vehicle safely and efficiently. I n

Australia, following stroke, survivors are restricted in driving for four weeks , and after TIA, they 
are restricted for two weeks. The driving restrictions in place after stroke and TIA are due to the 
risk of recurrent TIA and/or stroke in the days and w eeks after the event, and are not necessarily 
due to functional limitations after stroke. Even so, there are significant functional impairments

severity. What this literature review has not been able to identify, define or describe is the 
management o f RTD in patients who are diagnosed with stroke or TIA and who are discharged 
directly home from the acute hospital setting. This thesis will aim to generate new knowledge 
about how RTD is managed in patients diagnosed with stroke and TIA who are discharge d 
directly home from the acute hospital setting , and how to bridge the related practice -evidence  
gaps identified. Chapter three presents the findings of a systematic review which investigated 
the adherence to RTD guidelines in the acute hospital setting.

 5.2 Return  to driving after stroke: Knowledge of health professionals  
5.2.1 Introduction  
The ability to drive a motor vehicle has a significant impact on the quality of life of stroke 
survivors and is a major predictor of a stroke survivor’s return to independence (Griffen, 
Rapport, Bryer, & Scott, 2009 ; Liddle et al., 2009 ; Lister, 1999 ; Patomella, Johansson, & Tham, 
2009 ). The deficits that result from stroke and can impact the ability to drive a motor vehicle are 
well-researched (Fisk et al., 2002 ; Lee et al., 2003 ; McKay et al., 2011 ). The y include (i) upper

chunk_1294.text:
and lower limb sensorimotor dysfunction ; (ii) impairments in judgement, mental processing, 
comprehensi on and reaction time; and (iii) deficits in peripheral vision (Devos et al., 2011 ). 
 
Even if a person has a mild stroke, impairments such as visual field deficits, sensorimotor 
dysfunctio n and poor concentration can still be present during  the initial recovery phase of 
stroke. Not only can these deficits impact a person’s driving ability, he or she is also at risk of 
either recurrent stroke in the first month or recurrent TIA in the first week after a TIA (Hennessy 
& Britton, 2000 ). Rothwell and Warlow (2005 ) reported that 17% of TIA s occur on the same day 
of a stroke, 9% on the day before a stroke and 43% in the week preceding a stroke. Furthermore, 
following stroke , there is also a 9% incidence of seizures wi thin the first two years (Bladin et al., 
2000 ; Yale, Hansotia, K napp, & John, 2003 ). A stroke survivor who experiences a mild stroke is

chunk_1295.text:
2000 ; Yale, Hansotia, K napp, & John, 2003 ). A stroke survivor who experiences a mild stroke is 
often discharged directly home from the Acute Stroke Unit or acute medical ward after having 
only stayed in hospital for a few hours or days.  
 
In Australia, the guidelines entitled  “Assessing Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private 
Vehicle Drivers ” (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ) were developed by  the 
Australasian Road Transpor t and Traffic Agencies (Austroads) and the National Transport 
115
 
 
 Commis sion. The purpose  of these guidelines is to provide Australian health professionals with 
medical standards for licensing  and clinical guidelines  for determining fitness  to drive . These 
stipulate a four -week  restriction in driving after all strokes and a two-week res triction after TIA s. 
In addition, t he Australian Stroke Foundation ’s Guidelines for Stroke Management (National

chunk_1296.text:
In addition, t he Australian Stroke Foundation ’s Guidelines for Stroke Management (National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010 a)  recommend that stroke survivors be provided with verbal and 
written information about:  
• The impact of stroke on driving skills  and driving restrictions imposed after stroke  
• How to be cleared to drive at the end of the restriction period  
• The driver’s obligation to inform their State ’s or Territory’s Driver Licensing Authority 
of their stroke.  
 
Return to driving  after an acute admission for  TIA or stroke is an under -researched topic , as 
demonstrated by the findings in the systematic review  (Frith et al ., 2015) , which  identified only  
three  studies (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Johnston et al., 2004 ; McCarron et al., 2 008) that investigat ed 
RTD behaviours associated with patients who had TIA or  stroke and were discharged directly 
home  from an acute hospital . The review identified that less than 50%  of stroke survivors in the

chunk_1297.text:
United Kingdom received RTD education prior to leaving hospital , and about  one-third returned 
to dr iving during the restricted period. Th is evidence indicates that survivors of TIA or mild stroke 
may be at high risk of resuming driving because they have not been provided with RTD education 
and may  therefore be unaware they should not be driving. As the review contained no Australian 
data , what was missing from the literature was how well Australian health professionals are 
managing RTD after TIA or stroke in the acute setting and whether they are adhering to 
national ly-agreed RTD clinical guidelines.  
116
 
 
 The aim of this study was to assess the knowledge  about, and use of, RTD guidelines  
recommended by Austroads ’ guidelines  and the National Stroke Foundation ’s Clinical Guidelines 
for Stroke Management , among  Australian health professionals working with stroke survivors.

5.2.2.2 Participants  
Any Australian health professiona l working in the field of stroke was eligible to participate. The 
authors sought to obtain a cross -section of professionals from medicine, nursing and allied 
health.

were those  related to the driving restrictions following TIA and stroke  (questions 2 and 3) .

stroke -specific clinical networks in the different Australian States and Territories and via 
Australian universities offering health -related programs. A hard -copy invi tation was distributed 
at a national stroke conference. Recipients were also encouraged to forward the survey

Respondents to the survey were asked two knowledge -based questions about  restrictions in

recommended following stroke. Nearly two -thirds of health professionals (63% ; n=281) chose 
non-recommended responses to both qu estions.

5.2.4 Discussion  
This study identified that health professionals’ knowledge about RTD after stroke is limited, with 
many unaware of the recommended RTD restrictions after both stroke and TIA. The study’s 
respondents identified occupational therapists as th e most appropriate health professional s to 
provide education to people with TIA and stroke on restrictions in driving , and general 
practitioners as the most appropriate health professionals to provid e clearance to return to

chunk_1318.text:
practitioners as the most appropriate health professionals to provid e clearance to return to  
driving. However, it is importan t to bear in mind that more than 50% of respondents to the 
survey  were  occupational therapists. Even so, this raises concerns about the adequacy of RTD 
management , as evidence indicates that less than 50% of patients with recent stroke or TIA who 
129
 
 
 are disch arged directly home are referred to occupational therapists (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Frith 
et al., 2017 ).   
 
5.2.4.1 Knowledge of return -to-driving guidelines  
This study identified that only 1 in 5 healt h professionals correctly identified the four -week 
driving restriction after stroke and only 3 in 10 correctly identified the  two-week driving 
restriction after TIA.  Many responded that people with either a TIA or s troke should not return 
to driving until cleared to do so by a doctor. According to Austroads ’ Fitness to Drive Guidelines

chunk_1319.text:
(Aust roads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ) and the Stroke Foundation ’s Clinical 
Guidelines for Stroke (National Stroke Foundatio n, 2010a ), once the restriction period ends, 
medical clearance is required to return to driving. Therefore, this answer is partially correct . 
However, firstly, it means that stroke survivors may not be informed about the recommended 
restrictions ; and se condly, it assumes that the survivor will discuss this issue with his or her local 
doctor and that the doctor  is knowledgeable about RTD restrictions after stroke and TIA . What 
this study has not been able to identify is whether  the cohort of health profes sionals who 
answered “until told so by a doctor” are aware of the restriction period s after TIA and stroke or 
whether they are deferring to other health profession als to manage RTD. These findings suggest 
that a practice -evidence gap may exist in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines. Evidence

chunk_1320.text:
that a practice -evidence gap may exist in the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines. Evidence 
suggests that while the use of clinical guidelines in stroke can improve outcomes for stroke 
survivors, difficulties exist in the implementation of these guidelines (Hubbard et al., 2012 ). If a 
practice -evidence gap does exist, it may be the result of health professionals ’ skills and attitude s, 
culture within the health facility and availability of the guidelines (Kang & Schneck, 2004 ).  
 
130
 
 
 A promising finding is that health professionals working in hospitals were more aware of the 
restriction period following TIA and stroke . This appears to indicate that  survivors of TIA and 
stroke may be receiving  this information prior to leaving hospital.  However, due to the bias 
towards occupational therapists among the respondents , education may be provided by 
occupational therapist s, rather than by other members of the multidisciplinary team.

chunk_1321.text:
occupational therapist s, rather than by other members of the multidisciplinary team.   
 
5.2.4.2 Role  of local doctors  
The respondents in this study have indicated that health professionals rely on the medical 
profession , particularly a person’s general practitioner  (local doctor),  to provide advice about 
RTD after TIA and stroke . In everyday clinical practice, in a cohort of patients who are discharge d 
directly home from the acute hospital setting, GPs may be the only health professionals involved 
in the long term. Therefore, the role of managing a person’s RTD should, perhaps, default to the 
GP. E vidence suggests , however, that GPs are not necessarily  the best profession als to provide 
advice on RTD, as they are less likely to know RTD guidel ines (Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ) and are 
likely to find the assessment of driving ability  challe nging (Jang et al., 2007 ; Jones, Rouse -

chunk_1322.text:
likely to find the assessment of driving ability  challe nging (Jang et al., 2007 ; Jones, Rouse -
Watson, Beveridge, Sims, & Schattner, 2012 ). There is also a reluctance on the part of GPs to 
discuss driving with patients for fear of damaging the physician -patient relationship , and 
becaus e of the pressures of mandatory reporting in some places (Jang et al., 200 7; Liddle et al., 
2014 ; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ). This can create clinical variance between the advice one 
person may receive from a GP as opposed to what another pe rson may receive. A person may 
(i) return to driving when they are legally not supposed to , or (ii) be restricted in driving longer 
than is required, thus creating an increase d burden on daily life  and a reduced quality of life. 
This clinical variance in health professionals ’ advice  also has implications for the stroke survivor’s 
licensing  and insurance  responsibilities and the health professional ’s ethical, and sometimes

chunk_1323.text:
licensing  and insurance  responsibilities and the health professional ’s ethical, and sometimes 
legal, responsibilities  (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ). 
131
 
 
 5.2.4.3 Role of occupational therap ists 
Over 80% of respondents nominated the occupational therapist a s the most appropriate person 
to provide advice on RTD after stroke ; presumably, this is expected to occur whil e the patients 
are still in hospital. T he results of this study  indicate that occupational therapists  are more likely 
to provide  the recommended advice. Considering the high response rate from occupational 
therapists, it can be concluded that they themselves have identified their profession as having 
this role in RTD management .  
 
Literature suggests that the role of providing education on RTD whil e a patient is still in hospital 
lies with occupational therapists (Frith et al., 2015 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). There is extensive

chunk_1324.text:
lies with occupational therapists (Frith et al., 2015 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). There is extensive 
literature on the role occupational therapists play in assessing a person’s ability to drive (Devos 
et al., 2011 ; Korner -Bitensky et al., 2000 ; Korner -Bitensky, Sofer, Gelinas, & Mazer, 1998 ; 
Lundberg, Caneman, Samuelsson, Hakamies -Blomqvist, & Almkvist, 2003 ) and driver retraining 
(Akinwuntan, Devos, Verheyden, et al., 2010 ; Crotty & George, 2009 ; Devos et al., 2009 ; Mazer 
et al., 2003 ). However, this literature is based on a cohor t of stroke survivors who were in the 
rehabilitation phase of their recovery and not in the acute hospital setting. If, as the evidence 
suggests, occupational therapist s may see only 50% of patients with stroke and TIA  admitted to 
acute hospital s (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Frith et al., 2017 ), less than half of all patients  would be 
provided with education about driving if they were discharged directly home from the acute

chunk_1325.text:
provided with education about driving if they were discharged directly home from the acute 
setting. Stroke survivors who make a full recovery from stroke or have impairments which do 
not re quire inpatient rehabilitation are still at risk of recurrent stroke (Hennessy & Britton, 
2000 ). Reliance  on the occupational therapist to provide advice on RTD in the acute hospital 
setting potentially leads to a practice -evidence gap and may  be putting stroke survivors at risk 
of driving during restriction period s because they are unaware of the restriction s.  
132
 
 
 5.2.4.4 Influence of years of experience  
The number of years working in a chosen profession and the number of years working in the 
field of stroke influenced knowledge of RTD guidelines for stroke in this stu dy. Health 
professionals with less than one year ’s professional experience  or greater than 10 years ’ 
professional experience were less likely to know RTD restrictions following stroke and TIA. This

chunk_1326.text:
professional experience were less likely to know RTD restrictions following stroke and TIA. This 
may be due to inexperienced health professionals not being  aware of RTD g uidelines and more 
experienced health professionals not being aware that such guidelines have been revised . 
However, the re sults of this study revealed that  experienced health professionals are more likely 
to see a higher number of stroke su rvivors each month (for example, more than 40) when 
compared with  health professionals with less experience. If this is the case, a seemingly highly 
skilled and experienced workforce is not utilising readily available RTD guidelines . The question 
remains a s to why.   
 
5.2.5 Limitations  
A limitation of this study is the potential misinterpretation of the two knowledge -based 
questions. One respond ent indicated in the free -text section of the survey that there were two

chunk_1327.text:
questions. One respond ent indicated in the free -text section of the survey that there were two 
possible answers to the questions regarding restrictions in driving after TIA and stroke. The 
answer the researchers were looking for was “restricted in driving for two weeks” and 
“restricted in driving for four weeks” respectively . However , the response of “should  not drive 
until cleared by a medical professional” could technically also be correct as medical clearan ce is 
required prior to the TIA or stroke survivor ’s return  to driving. This misunderstanding could have 
impacted on some of the participants’ responses  to these questions , as 45% answered this way 
to the TIA question and 77% to the stroke question. Further limitation s include the bias towards 
133
 
 
 occupational therapists being the main respondents to the survey  as well as the researchers 
being unable to deter mine the potential sample size for the survey .

5.2.6 Conclusion  
There are two key questions that remain unanswered following the results of this study. Firstly, 
are health professionals aware of the restriction periods  present after TIA and stroke? Second ly, 
if the health professional is unaware, are people with recent TIA or stroke at risk of being  
misinformed regarding driving restrictions ? 
 
Both occupational therapists and doctors have been identified as having an important role to 
play in providing education on RTD. However , due to the limited number of responses from 
health professionals other than  occupational therapists  and physicians, this may not reflect the 
views of all health professionals working in the field of stroke. Further investigation is required 
to gain a clearer understanding  of the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines among  all health

guidelines after stroke  
5.3.1 Introduction  
Acute hospitals in Australia admit about 30,000 patients with stroke each year. Discharge 
planning is vital for patients who transition from acute -care facilities directly back into the 
community  (National Stroke Foundation, 2015 ). While  RTD management plan s should be 
provided as part of th eir discharge care plan s (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ), only 44% of

chunk_1330.text:

stroke survivors are dischar ged home with plan s (National Stroke Foundation, 2015 ).  Australia’s  
Stroke Foundati on Guidelines for Stroke Management  (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ) 
recommend  that patients be provided with both verbal and wri tten information about the 
impact of stroke on driving skills; driving restrictions imposed after stroke; how to be cleared to 
drive at the completion of the restriction period; and the stroke survivor’s obligation to inform 
their State’s or Territory’s Driver Licensing Authority  of the stroke. The restrictions for driving a 
private vehicle recommend a four -week  restriction in driving after all strokes and a two-week 
restriction in driving after TIA  (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ; National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010a ). For Australian health professionals, these recommended driving

restriction s, and other medical standards for licensing , are published in The Australian Road 
Transport and Traffic Agencies ’ (Austroads ’) and the National Transport Commission ’s Assessing 
Fitness to Drive for Commercial and Private Vehicle Drivers  (Austroads and National T ransport 
Commission, 2016 ). At the end of the restriction period, clearance by a medical professional to 
return to driving is also recommended.  
 
Evidence is emerging of a practice -evidence gap in the use of RTD g uidelines in patients who are 
discharged directly home from the acute hospital setting  (Frith et al., 2015 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). A

RTD guidelines , both in the health professionals’ responsibility to discuss RTD with the stroke

survivor  prior to being discharg ed home from the acute hospital  setting , and in the patient’s 
adherence to the stipulated driving restrictions. The systematic review revealed three  studies, 
all based in the United Kingdom , highlighting that less than 50% of stroke survivors discharged 
directly home from the acute setting received education on RTD and that provision of education 
was highly associated with whether or not a stroke  survivor was seen by occupational therapist s 
during the admission  (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Johnston et al., 2004 ; McCarron  et al., 2008 ). As only 
50% of stroke survivors  are seen  by an occupational therapist during their acute admission s 
(Biswas et al., 2006 ; Frith et  al., 2017 ), this raises concerns about adherence to RTD guidelines  
and the role s other health professionals play in the management of RTD after stroke . This study

aims to explore  the knowledge and use of RTD guidelines among  Australian health professionals

This study reports on the analysis of the qualitative data in the responses to a national survey o f 
Australian health professionals’ knowledge and use of RTD guidelines following stroke.  
 
5.3.2 Methods  
This study is a parallel paper presenting qualitative data from a survey which has been described 
elsewhere. This study was approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee of the University 
of Newcastle , Australia  (Appendix 4) . A cross -sectional , anonymous survey was used to gather 
information from Australian health professionals working in the field of stroke on their 
knowledge and use of RTD guidelines  (Appendix 3) . Details  of the full survey have been reported

elsewhere  (Frith, James, Hubbard, & Warren -Forward, 2016b ). The data analysed for this study

Inductive thematic analysis was used to investigate respon ses to the survey question , “Is there 
anything else you would like to add ?”. This enabled an in -depth, exploratory investigation of the 
qualitative data  (Kelly, 1985 ). Responses were read through several times to identify common 
sub-themes within the text. Data that were relevant to the phenomena  in question were 
extracted and placed into an Excel spreadsheet. Following reading of the transcripts, two 
authors (JF and CJ) used an inductive approach to code data into relevant and meaningful 
categories  (Bowling, 2002 ). A meeting occurred between these two researchers to merge 
categories into themes. This allowed for intersubjective agreement on the final themes  (Kvale, 
2007 ). To ensure validity of the interpretation of the data, key themes were checked for 
confirming and disconfirming evidence within the dataset  (Erickson, 1986 ). To remove bias and

5.3.4 Discussion  
This study revealed that Australian health professionals involved in the management of RTD 
after stroke report ed uncertainty and inconsistencies for health profe ssionals and patients alike, 
and that health professionals may be deferring to others , rather than manag ing this  issue  
themselves. Other concerns raised were the lack of RTD knowledge, education and resources 
for health professionals  and patients , and conf usion about who is responsible for educating and 
advising patients about RTD management . The overall result points to potential inconsistencies

advising patients about RTD management . The overall result points to potential inconsistencies 
in the advice and  education about driving restrictions post -stroke  that stroke survivors are 
receiving .

 5.3.4.1  Lack of knowledge  
Despite the availability of clinical guidelines that define recommended practices  in the 
management of RTD after stroke  (Austroads and Na tional Transport Commission, 2016 ; National 
Stroke Foundation, 2010a ), this study identified that Australian health professionals working in 
stroke are unclear about  how to manage t he RTD process for patients with stroke and TIA. 
Austroad s’ guidelines  (Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ) and the National 
Stroke Foundation’s  Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management (National Stroke Foundation, 
2010a ) include clearly state d recommendations related to survivors of stroke and TIA , and also

chunk_1351.text:
2010a ) include clearly state d recommendations related to survivors of stroke and TIA , and also  
recommend that all stroke survivors receive both verbal and written information on RTD 
restrictions prior to leaving hospital, be informed of their responsibility to notify the Driver 
Licen sing Authority of their stroke , and be cleared by a medical practitioner prior to return to 
driving  (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a ). These guidelines have been put in place to support 
health professionals in their role of providing education to patients a bout driving after stroke  
(Austroads and National Transport Commission, 2016 ). Yet the findings in this study indicate 
that knowledge of, and compliance with  these guidelines is perceived as complex, confusing and 
inconsistent. The comments made by responden ts regarding lack of knowledge reflect those in 
the qualitative data  of the  survey. Out of a total of 455 health professionals across Australia who

completed the main survey, only 12% ( n=53) correctly answered both questions regarding 
restrictions in driving after TIA and stroke  (Frith, James, Hubbard, & Warren -Forward, 2016a ).  
 
This study finds  that health professionals working in stroke are concerned about doctors’ 
potential lack of knowledge of RTD guidelines and process , a concern supported by previous 
studies. For example, Goodyear and Roseveare (2003)  found  that only 11% of doctors working 
within an acute hospital setting in the United Kingdom knew the RTD guidelines for stroke.

This study identified a perception that occupational therapists and doctors have the primary 
responsibility  for RTD management after stroke. While it is important for occupational therapists 
and doctors to be well-educated in the use of RTD guidelines (Batool, Roberts, Kaira, & 
Manawadu, 2014 ; Brooke & Southward, 2006 ; Goodyear & Roseveare, 2003 ; Jang et al., 2007 ;

othe r health professionals to be educated in RTD management as they may have contact with 
patients recovering from stroke during professional  contact  at different phases of recovery. For 
example, in the acute hospital setting, only 50% of patients with stroke may see occupational 
therapist s (Biswas et al., 2006 ; Frith et al., 2017 ). If RTD education is  left to occupational 
therapists  alone,  the 50% of patients who do not see occupational therapists may be unaware 
of driving restrictions after stroke and TIA. To ensure that all patients with stroke or TIA who  
own current driver’s licence s are provided with RTD education that complies with the guidelines, 
this study support the Stroke Foundation’s (National Stroke Foundation, 2010a )

recommendation that all health professionals working in stroke receive education on the

5.3.4.2 De ferring responsibility  
Health professionals who mak e decisions or provid e education about a patient’s ability to 
resume driving after stroke must be adequately informed, educated and resourced  and, in turn, 
confident  about  fulfil ling this responsibility  (S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ). Even though Australia’s 
nationally -agreed clinical g uidelines  recommend that all health professionals involved in the 
field of stroke have a responsibility to discuss RTD with stroke survivor s (National Stroke 
Foundation, 2010a ), health professionals in this study  report ed that some are defer ring to 
147
 
 
 others, such as to GPs. This may be problematic, as GP s may be unaware of their assumed role

in managing driving after stroke and/or uncertain about what advice and education they should 
be providing. According to the study by Jang et al. (2007) , 50% of GPs did not feel confident 
assessing fitness  to drive or felt qualified to do  so. There is also evidence that they may avoid 
discussing the issue of driv ing in order to preserve their relationships with their patients  (Jang 
et al., 2007 ; S. Marshall & Gilbert, 1999 ), or they may see it  as a lower priority compared with  
the management of other health issues  (Liddle et al., 2014 ). To ensure that all patients with 
stroke or TIA who own current driver’s licence s are provided with RTD education that complies 
with the guidelines, the authors of this study recomme nd the introduction of an integrated care 
plan which includes documentation about RTD after stroke and TIA.

5.3.4.3 Mandatory reporting  
This study identified mandatory reporting as having an impact on health professionals’ 
adherence to RTD guidelines, p articularly in those Australian States and Territories where this is 
a requirement. Respondents fel t that current RTD guidelines did  not support mandatory 
reporting requirements. Mandatory reporting was seen as a burden that negatively impacted 
adherence t o RTD guidelines , and health professionals avoided discussing RTD with patients 
because of this.  Interestingly, health professionals who were not mandated to report concerns 
about a person’s ability to drive felt that mandatory reporting should occur and would result in 
increased compliance with RTD guidelines. As is the case in Australia, Canada  has differing 
mandatory reporting requirements across the country. In a cohort of Canadian doctor s, S. 
Marshall et al. (2012)  found differing views on mandatory reporting between those who were

Marshall et al. (2012)  found differing views on mandatory reporting between those who were 
bound by them and those who were not. The clinical practices of doctors  were compared 
between areas with mandatory reporting requirements and areas where discretionary reporting 
was allowed . In the areas with mandatory reporting, fewer doctors assessed their patients’ 
148
 
 
 ability to drive, and more doctors reported their patients ’ inability to dri ve. The practice of doing 
fewer  assessments in states with mandatory reporting was attributed to the perceived negative 
impact on the doctor -patient  relationship  and the  doctors’  lack of education about assessing 
fitness to drive  (S. Marshall et al., 2012 ). The evidence indicates , therefore, that mandatory 
reporting may not necessarily ensure co mpliance with  RTD guidelines after stroke  and that 
education on RTD guidelines is of greater importance . To reduce confusion and increase

chunk_1358.text:
education on RTD guidelines is of greater importance . To reduce confusion and increase 
consistency, it is recommended that there be a nationally consistent approach to the mandatory 
reporting requirements related to stroke and TIA across Australia , applied  irrespective of the 
State or Territory  in which the person resides . 
 
5.3.5 Strengths and limitations  
These findings provide an in -depth investigation into Australian health professionals ’ concerns 
about RTD issues after stro ke. However, these findings cannot be generalised  to other countries.  
A limitation of this study is that only 70 participants of  the survey’ s 455 respondents provided 
additional comments. There was also a selection bias towards occupat ional therapists and those 
working in the Australian States of New South Wales and Queensland.    
 
5.3.6 Conclusion  
This study provide d a “window” into the reported confusion, complexity and inconsistency that

health professionals are experiencing in the m anagement of RTD in stroke survivors. To manage 
this, health professionals may be reluctant to engage with this issue, may defer to oth er health 
professionals or may avoid it altogether.  This, in turn , is creating confusion for the stroke 
survivor in how t o manage RTD. E ducation of health professionals in RTD guidelines is required

5.4 Chapter synopsis  
This chapter presented quantitative and qualitative analys es of the results from a national 
survey of Australian health professionals’ knowledge and use of RTD guidelines. The studies

chunk_1360.text:
survey of Australian health professionals’ knowledge and use of RTD guidelines. The studies 
revealed that health professionals lack knowledge about driving restrictions after stroke and are 
uncertain regarding  who is responsi ble for managing RTD. Health professionals are deferring to 
others , with occupational therapists and general practitioners  being seen as the key health 
professionals involved in the management of RTD. As demonstrated in Chapters  three and four, 
a practice -evidence gap has emerged in the use of RTD guidelines in the acute hospital setting . 
As a result, there are inconsistencies in the content and timing of education provided to stroke 
survivors. Chapters three, four and five have indicated a compelling need for an education 
strategy to be made available in Austroads ’ guidelines and the National Stroke Foundation’s 
Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management regarding RTD, targeting all Australian health

chunk_1361.text:
Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management regarding RTD, targeting all Australian health 
professionals working in the field of stroke. Chapter six presents the development, 
implementation and assessment of an electronic learning module on returning to driving after 
stroke.

  6.1 Chapter overview  
The results of the previous studies presented in this thesis have  revealed that clinical guidelines 
for the management of return  to driving (RTD) after stroke may be inconsistent , as evidenced 
by the documentation about RTD education and management in patients with stroke and 
transient ischaemic attack (TIA) who are discharged directly home from the acute hospital 
setting. The findings also revealed that a contributing factor to this practice -evidence gap is the

chunk_1372.text:
lack of knowledge of clinical guidelines by health professionals and the reported uncertainty  
regarding their roles and responsibilities. As a result, health professionals tend to defer the 
management of RTD to others , and p ersons with stroke and TIA are often left confused about 
how to manage their own RTD. While t hey may turn to their general practitioners for advice , the 
results of the studies have revealed that general practitioners may also lack the skills and 
experience  to adequately manage RTD. The studies in this thesis so far indicate that a clinically -
accessible strategy is needed to educate health professionals on the management of RTD after 
stroke and TIA in order to bridge the practice -evidence gap and ensure that  all patients with 
stroke and TIA receive documented RTD management plan s prior to being discharged home 
from the acute hospital setting. This chapter presents a clinically -accessible strategy in the

chunk_1373.text:
from the acute hospital setting. This chapter presents a clinically -accessible strategy in the 
development and implementation of an electronic learning  module which provides evidence -
based education on RTD after stroke and TIA.
